channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Reserve Bank of Australia Will Do Whatever It Takes to Lower Inflation, Deputy Gov Says
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia sees the country’s inflation rate as too high and will take all necessary measures to bring it under control, a top central bank official said.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: China’s Consumer Inflation Eases, Producer Prices Stay in Decline
item.description: China’s consumer inflation softened at the start of 2026 after hitting a near three-year high in December, weighed down by falling food prices.

item.title: Dallas Fed President Lorie Logan said she believes the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate stance is set well for the risks facing the economy
item.description: Lorie Logan’s comments are sign she might be reluctant to support a return to cutting rates at Fed’s coming meetings.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Fed’s Hammack: Monetary Policy Is in a Good Place to Stay on Hold
item.description: Cleveland Fed President Beth Hammack said the Federal Reserve can err on the side of patience as it assesses the impact of recent rate reductions.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: Kenya’s Central Bank Cuts Key Lending Rate
item.description: Kenya’s central bank cut its key lending rate as East Africa’s largest economy continued a policy-loosening cycle to boost private-sector lending and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: U.S. Retail Sales Unexpectedly Flat in December
item.description: The softer-than-expected data feed into economists’ concerns about a fragile consumer economy
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Soaring profits and stocks funnel more of GDP toward companies, their top employees and shareholders. AI will intensify this trend, writes Greg Ip.
item.description: Soaring profits and stocks funnel more of GDP toward companies, their top employees and shareholders. AI will intensify this trend.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Fed’s Miran Says Dollar Needs ‘Really Big Move’ to Affect Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve governor Stephen Miran said the dollar would need to register a steeper fall than it already has to affect inflation, and that he does not view the dollar’s weakness as having material consequences on monetary policy so far.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: ECB Unlikely to React to Short-Lived Slowdown in Inflation, Nagel Says
item.description: A short-lived decline in inflation that takes it below target is unlikely to prompt action by the European Central Bank, Bundesbank President Joachim Nagel said in a speech at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Bank of France Governor Villeroy to Step Down in June, Before the End of His Term
item.description: The early departure means his successor will be appointed before the next presidential election, rather than after.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Uganda’s Central Bank Holds Key Lending Rate at 9.75%
item.description: Uganda’s central bank maintained its key lending rate at 9.75%, citing rising inflationary pressure and high oil prices amid sustained geopolitical uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Taiwan Exports Start 2026 Strong in Bright Sign for Economy
item.description: Taiwan’s exports hit the fastest growth since early 2010, as AI-powered demand continues unabated.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: The Trump economy in 2025 was a roller coaster, yet one thing remained constant: Americans are focused on prices. Here’s what a sampling of people across the spectrum have to say.
item.description: Some are living close to the economic edge; others are spending freely and seeing their wealth rise. But Americans of all stripes can’t stop talking about prices.
item.dc:creator: Jeanne Whalen

item.title: The pace of hiring in the U.S. has dropped off precipitously for a number of reasons, ranging from workers staying in their jobs to tariff uncertainties that make it difficult for companies to plan
item.description: A ‘deep freeze’ has enveloped the U.S. labor market. A whole bunch of factors are at play.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: President Trump chose a Federal Reserve chair he thinks he can count on to lower interest rates. History suggests three different ways presidents have come to regret that bet.
item.description: President Trump thinks his new chair can deliver low interest rates. Three presidents in the past learned otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Has Climbed in February, Michigan Survey Says
item.description: Consumer sentiment ticked up to 57.3 in February, according to a preliminary reading from the University of Michigan’s monthly survey, a positive signal that Americans’ economic mood is improving despite longstanding anxieties about inflation and the job market.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Industrial Production Declined at End of 2025
item.description: Production declined 1.1% overall in 2025, with economists expecting that to be the bottom of an industrial trough for Europe’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The resignation of Argentina’s statistics chief over delays in updating the inflation index has stirred up memories of price meddling
item.description: The resignation of Argentina’s statistics chief over delays in updating the inflation index has stirred up memories of price meddling.
item.dc:creator: Silvina Frydlewsky

item.title: The U.S. job market is off to a rough start in the new year, with companies announcing more layoff
item.description: Ahead of the government’s delayed January jobs report, a mix of other federal and private data points to a rough start to the new year.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: U.S. Economy Shed Nearly 1 Million Job Openings Last Year
item.description: The number of open jobs in the U.S. economy fell to just over 6.5 million in December from about 7.5 million at the end of 2024, evidence of how demand for workers has sputtered in an uneven labor market.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Rose Last Week
item.description: U.S. jobless claims rose more than expected last week, but still showed no major red flags in the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: Eurozone Retail Sales Sank at End of 2025
item.description: Sales fell more than expected in December, as the rebound in household spending that is expected to help the economy in 2026 remains fragile.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The U.S. has agreed to work with Japan, Mexico and the European Union on the development of critical minerals used in industries such as defense
item.description: The pacts seek to establish a “preferential trade zone” that would counter China’s dominance in the sector.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Without Immigrants, U.K. Economy Would Be Smaller, More Indebted, Says NIESR
item.description: The U.K.’s leading economic research body also said it expects inflation to settle at the Bank of England’s 2% target later this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Home builders are proposing new policies to the White House, looking for help to unload the biggest glut of housing inventory in 15 years
item.description: Companies are devising a plan for a federally backed “rent-to-own” program to help reduce the biggest surplus of homes in many years.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: South Korea Exports Off to Strong Start in 2026
item.description: South Korea’s exports started the year on a strong note, with outbound shipments surging in January on more working days and robust semiconductor demand.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: China Agrees to Lower Tariffs by Half on U.K. Whisky
item.description: The U.K. government said it expects whisky exports to China to be worth roughly $345.2 million to the economy over the next five years as tariffs are lowered to 5% from 10%.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Irish Economy Soared in 2025 on Weight-Loss Drugs Boom
item.description: Ireland’s GDP was 12.6% higher on year, the fastest expansion since 2021, even as Trump raised tariffs on imports from Europe and urged businesses to bring their production to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Property Market Recovers Post-Budget Jitters But Price Growth Still Slow
item.description: House prices rose at a slower pace in 2025 compared with the year before, as uncertainty about the government’s budget plans weighed on buyer demand.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: A 1990s initiative to replace housing projects with mixed-income developments gave children an economic lift as adults, new research finds
item.description: A 1990s government initiative to replace housing projects with mixed-income developments gave children an economic lift as adults, new research finds.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Consumer Confidence Dropped to 12-Year Low in January, per Conference Board
item.description: The monthly survey’s primary index dropped from 94.2 in December to 84.5 in January as the economic mood worsened across ages and income levels.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Rocked by growth-sapping shocks, countries around the world are rolling out large fiscal stimulus packages financed by bumper budget deficits
item.description: Rearmament, an aging population, technological change and fear of voters are fueling a risky trend.
item.dc:creator: Tom Fairless

item.title: The build-to-rent business looks poised to take off after President Trump exempted the industry from his regulations on large investors
item.description: The build-to-rent business looks poised to take off after Trump exempted this industry from his regulations on large investors.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Improved in January, Michigan Survey Finds
item.description: Consumers felt a bit better about the economy in January as sentiment lifted off from near-historical lows reached late last year, according to the University of Michigan’s monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Business Activity Picks Up in Parts of Europe and Asia
item.description: Business activity in the U.S. and a number of large economies across Europe and Asia picked up at the start of the year, with signs of a rebound in export orders as the global economy adjusts to the increase in U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: President Trump issued an executive order on Tuesday laying out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases
item.description: President issued an executive order on Tuesday that laid out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto
